title: acropalypse screenshot recovery utility

last_post.content:
CVE-2023-21036 / acropalypse is absolutely bonkers.

Apparently for 5+ years the cropping / editing tools for screenshots on Google Pixel phones was only overwriting the start of the screenshot PNG file, but not truncating.

All screenshots shared for the past 5+ years might have data recoverable from them. Demo available at https://acropalypse.app/

Google still hasn't communicated anything on this.

(h/t ItsSimonTime on Musk's site)

title: A Utah parent says the Bible contains porn and should be removed from school libraries. Here’s their full challenge.

last_post.content:
A Utah parent says the Bible contains porn and should be removed from school libraries. Here’s their full challenge. The parent writes that the book should be considered indecent under Utah’s new book banning law, after seeing the other titles that have been pulled.

“Incest, onanism, bestiality, prostitution, genital mutilation, fellatio, dildos, rape, and even infanticide,” the parent wrote in their request, listing topics they found concerning in the religious text. “You’ll no doubt find that the Bible, under Utah Code Ann. § 76-10-1227, has ‘no serious values for minors’ because it’s pornographic by our new definition.” https://www.sltrib.com/news/education/2023/03/22/utah-parent-says-bible-contains/

title: The Librarians Are Not OK

last_post.content:
Whether librarians at your institution have faculty status or not, they should be treated as equitable partners with their own disciplinary expertise. We contribute just as much to the teaching-research-service mission of the institution, even if we're not instructors of record.

I'm grateful to have faculty status (including tenure) in the California State University System, but librarians like me are a growing minority. And even with that status, I regularly have to assert my faculty status, even with teaching faculty who respect me, and remind folks that I do what they do. (I suspect I have it easier than many of my library colleagues because of my PhD.)

#AcademicLibraries #Librarians #AcademicChatter

https://www.chronicle.com/article/the-librarians-are-not-ok

title: ChatGPT Gets Its “Wolfram Superpowers”!

last_post.content:
"Under the hood, ChatGPT is formulating a query for Wolfram|Alpha—then sending it to Wolfram|Alpha for computation, and then “deciding what to say” based on reading the results it got back."

title: https://thi.ng/geom

last_post.content:
Just released and a very useful outcome from my recent #AxiDraw painting endeavors: https://thi.ng/geom now has a new function to split polylines into shorter segments of a given max. arc length (think max draw distance for a brush). The function also works for groups (recursively) and supports non-polyline shape types, as long as the latter can be converted into one (most of the lib's 2D shape types can, e.g. circles, bezier curves, paths, rects, other polygons etc.). Here's a tiny example to illustrate:

#ReleaseFriday #ThingUmbrella #Geometry #SVG

title: Creating PublicSpaces | Digital Government: Research and Practice

last_post.content:
Very excited to have published this new article, "Creating PublicSpaces" with my friends Jose Van Dijck and Geert-Jan Boegarts about how the Netherlands is taking digital public infrastructure and "values-led institutions" seriously, in ACM DGOV. https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3582578

GJ is the founder of PublicSpaces, a remarkable coalition of public broadcasters, cultural institutions and other public institutions in the Netherlands, seeking alternatives to commercial, surveillant and closed software.

José and I both advise the group, and we realized we were looking at an interesting market sector: organizations whose values conflict with traditional business models to produce and support software and other digital infrastructures.

GJ and PublicSpaces have created a model that helps orgs assess what software they're dependent on, how it conflicts with their values and how they might move onto more ideologically consistent infrastructures.

title: Copyright and Artificial Intelligence | U.S. Copyright Office

last_post.content: The Copyright Office has launched an initiative to examine the copyright law and policy issues raised by artificial intelligence (AI) technology, including the scope of copyright in works generated using AI tools and the use of copyrighted materials in AI training. After convening public listening sessions in the first half of 2023 to gather information about current technologies and their impact, the Office will publish a notice of inquiry in the Federal Register. https://copyright.gov/ai/?loclr=eanco

title: Really Sans Case Study

last_post.content:
I recommend reading this case study if you are interested in any of the following things:

• Animated Bézier curves.
• 1970s typography.
• Pantograph engraving machines.
• Photographically modifying letters with lenses.
• Fonts designed to work at specific point sizes.
• The typography of the advertising headline.
• A flexible new sans serif typeface designed for contemporary use.

title: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.12712.pdf

last_post.content:
I'm less sanguine about LLMs than I was in December when I said they're essentially "asking a supercomputer to get really good at mansplaining."

I really encourage folks to check out this paper on some of GPT4's capabilities.
https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.12712.pdf

Some of this is undoubtedly overstated. And none of this disputes the very real concerns about bias, misuse, and disinformation.

But look at some of these examples (pics attached). It's hard to reconcile with "word prediction on steroids."

title: schopie1 (@schopie1@hcommons.social)

last_post.content:
My colleague @schopie1 and I have been talking for some time about what might be possible if academic annual review processes were seen as formative (what will make it possible for you do great work in the years ahead) rather than summative (did you do enough this year). He's actively working on a framework for Formative Annual Review (FAR), and I am super excited about where it might lead us.

Edited to add the link I forgot to include: https://hcommons.social/@schopie1/110080183575265341

title: https://10print.org/

last_post.content:
I'm reading 10PRINT https://10print.org/; it's fun.

On p27 they suggest a variant on the classic 10PRINT program called TWO WALLS, which use two walls to print a random maze. The code is a bit ugly because it uses characters 181 and 184:

10 print chr$(181 +(int(rnd(1)+0.5)*3));:goto10

but they missed the fact that you can use 225 and 226 instead:

20 printchr$(225.5+rnd(1));:goto10

Mine is a one char/one bit change from the original.

(images are theirs first, mine second)

#10Print

title: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.13966.pdf

last_post.content:
"The very terms used by the researchers who named these benchmark assessments—“general language understanding,” “natural language inference,” “reading comprehension,” “commonsense reasoning,” and so on—reveal an assumption that humanlike understanding is required to perform well on these tasks. But do these tasks actually require such understanding? Not necessarily." - @melaniemitchell, https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.13966.pdf

/cc @matthew, @vaurora

title: A fake news frenzy: why ChatGPT could be disastrous for truth in journalism

last_post.content:
Essential reading from @emilybell -- reputable journalism isn't just "information", much less text. It's the product of careful investigation by the journalist within frameworks for fact-checking, etc.

Anyone excited about the prospect of using #ChatGPT etc to produce journalism is really only excited about lining their own pockets.

https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2023/mar/03/fake-news-chatgpt-truth-journalism-disinformation

title: Blog | Quantity is for Production, Quality is for Performance

last_post.content:
New from my lab:
"Quantity is for Production, Quality is for Performance"

Why do we struggle to talk about developer productivity? One reason: we're often *not* talking about it at all!

Frankly, @CSLee and I want you to stop arguing about whether a single magical measure is the right or wrong one and start thinking big about what our teams need and how we use information about our work over time. Developers deserve better.

https://www.pluralsight.com/blog/learning-and-development/what-productivity-really-means-in-software-engineering

title: The script I use to set up a new mac just the way I like it

last_post.content:
Every time I set up a new mac, I update my install script that gets things most of the way installed for me.

Here's the newest version, in case it's helpful to anybody: https://gist.github.com/llimllib/c4dd0a98a426022b0365d4c0a9090460

- ask you for your new computer's name and set it
- set a bunch of preferences
- install homebrew and a base set of packages, both CLI and apps
- install programming language environments with `asdf`

The script's been in (very intermittent) development for 7 years now!

title: OpenAI, MinIO, And Why You Should Always Use docker-cli-scan To Keep Your Supply chAIn Clean

last_post.content:
🚨 If anyone is playing around with the new #ChatGPT "plugins" and using the demo Docker bits from OpenAI, you would be well-served to 👀 this new post from my team on an actively exploited weakness in the version of MinIO they have as one of the container layers.

Your endpoint _WILL eventually get popped_ if you do not update the layer to the latest MinIO.

https://www.greynoise.io/blog/openai-minio-and-why-you-should-always-use-docker-cli-scan-to-keep-your-supply-chain-clean

title: Elon Musk Today

last_post.content: It wasn't until digging into Musk background after the whole going after the guy who criticized his cave rescue submarine stunt that I realized how many times he just made shit up as on the verge of existing or 1-2 years away tops to have it be total BS. Good news, now there is a site that tracks it. It is truly mind bending that people take what he says at face value any longer. He is more grifter and charlatan than "real world Tony Stark" tech genius. The data is all there for you to see for yourself. #ElonMusk #MuskIsADick elonmusk.today/

title: what-is-dh-the-album.netlify.a...

Reminder that voting in the 2022 #DHAwards closes this weekend (March 26)

My website "What is #DigitalHumanities? The Album" is a nominee in the DH for fun category.

If you like your DH set to popular music but still well footnoted  and encoded in TEI, then check it out (and maybe vote for it!)

As with all DH projects, it's a work in progress; the next song 'Epistolary' (networks) is almost ready for release!

title: https://firstdonoharm.dev

last_post.content:
#TodayILearned about the Hippocratic License 3.0 (HL3): An Ethical License for Open Source Communities, which "aims to confront the potential harms and abuses technology can have on fundamental human rights. It empowers open source communities to establish a clear set of ethical standards that licensees must abide by in order to adopt their code."¹ There's a builder tool² that allows you to customize the license with specific areas of concern.

¹ https://firstdonoharm.dev
² https://firstdonoharm.dev/build/

title: Blog | Quantity is for Production, Quality is for Performance

last_post.content:
Hey! Check out this piece I wrote with @grimalkina! We did a deep lit review across the management and social sciences to talk about wtf #productivity ACTUALLY means, how it’s conflated with things like #production and #performance and how we need to move past looking for a single metric and instead think about #developers holistically and in the context of systems. #softwareengineering
